Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 to renewable solar fuels is considered to be a promising strategy to simultaneously solve both global warming and energy crises.However, development of a superior photocatalytic system with high product selectivity for CO 2 reduction under solar light is the prime requisite.Herein, a series of nature-inspired Z-scheme g C 3 N 4 FeWO 4 composites are prepared for higher performance and selective CO 2 reduction to CO as solar fuel under solar light.The novel direct Z-scheme

clearly demonstrate that the staggered band structure between FeWO 4 and C 3 N 4 reflecting the nature-inspired Z-scheme system not only favors superior spatial separation of the electron-hole pair in g-C 3 N 4 FeWO 4 but also shows good reusability.The present work provides unprecedented insights for constructing the direct Z-scheme by mimicking the nature for high performance and selective photocatalytic CO 2 reduction into solar fuels under solar light.

in Na 2 SO 3 neutral solution in the dark at a frequency of 10 kHz. 2.4.Photocatalytic Measurements.Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction experiments were carried out in a stainless steel photoreactor with a quartz window setup under the illumination of a solar simulator (100 mWcm 2 ) with a xenon lamp of 300 W.About 50 mg of the sample was dispersed in 20 mL of 0.5 M Na 2 SO 3 .Prior to irradiation, the reaction setup was purged with He (20 mLmin for 1 h) to remove the air and then purged with high purity CO 2 (1

FeWO 4 .The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction performance of the pristine and composite photocatalysts was evaluated under solar light using Na 2 SO 3 as a hole scavenger.The products were analyzed in regular intervals of 1 h, as shown in Figure 7. CO (CO 2 2H 2e - CO H 2 O) was found to be the main and direct product of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.However, H 2 (2H 2e - H 2 ) was also detected because of water-splitting reaction, whereas holes were consumed by Na 2 SO 3 (Na 2 SO 3 2OH - 2h Na 2 SO 4 H 2

2 SO 3 2OH - 2h Na 2 SO 4 H 2 O).The control experiments (Supporting Information, Figure S8) in the absence of a photocatalyst or light or CO 2 were also performed, confirming that the obtained CO solely originates from CO 2 photoreduction and that light, CO 2 , and photocatalyst are essential for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction. Very interestingly, C 3 N 4 FeWO 4 composites showed excellent performance for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction under solar light irradiation, as shown in Figure 7a.After 5 h of

result.query:
Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.
Please only select the generation from the provided possible choices.
Possible Choices:
Light_source: ['UV', 'Solar', 'UV-Vis', 'Monochromatic', 'Solar Simulator']
Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
Light_source: XXX
Lamp: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: -1 with a BaSO 4 pellet as the reference.Photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the samples were recorded at room temperature on a steady-state spectroflurometer FLS 980 (Edinburgh Instruments) equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp.The ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectrum (UV-vis DRS) was obtained by using a SHIMADZU UV-3600 plus UV-vis-near-infrared spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere attachment.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was carried out using a Thermo K-Alpha

out using a Thermo K-Alpha spectrometer using microfocused and monochromated Al K radiation with 1486.6 eV energy. 2.3.Photoelectrochemical Measurements.The on-off transient measurements were carried out in a three-electrode system using an Autolab PGSTAT 30 potentiostat under the illumination of a solar simulator (Newport) with an ultraviolet (UV) ( 420 nm) cutoff filter and 100 mWcm 2 power density.AgAgCl was used as the reference electrode, and platinum was used as the counter electrode.The sample

in Na 2 SO 3 neutral solution in the dark at a frequency of 10 kHz. 2.4.Photocatalytic Measurements.Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction experiments were carried out in a stainless steel photoreactor with a quartz window setup under the illumination of a solar simulator (100 mWcm 2 ) with a xenon lamp of 300 W.About 50 mg of the sample was dispersed in 20 mL of 0.5 M Na 2 SO 3 .Prior to irradiation, the reaction setup was purged with He (20 mLmin for 1 h) to remove the air and then purged with high purity CO 2 (1

purged with high purity CO 2 (1 bar, 5 mL min) for 1 h.During irradiation, 1 mL of the gaseous product from the setup was sampled, and subsequent analysis was done by gas chromatography (Shimadzu Tracera GC-2010 Plus) with a barrier ionization detector and He carrier gas.Blank experiments were carried out in the absence of CO 2 and light to confirm that these two factors are indispensable for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction.For stability test, the selected photocatalyst was collected after each run

counter electrode.The sample coated on fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) served as the working electrode.The electrolyte used was 0.5 M Na 2 SO 3 .The photoelectrodes were fabricated by preparing the slurry in a mortar and pestle by adding 40 mg of the sample, 200 L of Nafion (5), and 1 mL of isopropyl alcohol.The obtained paste was coated on FTO with 1 cm 2 area and heated at 250 C for 1 h to get a homogenous film.Mott-Schottky (MS) plots were recorded at a scan rate of 10 mVs in Na 2 SO 3 neutral solution

counter electrode.The sample coated on fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) served as the working electrode.The electrolyte used was 0.5 M Na 2 SO 3 .The photoelectrodes were fabricated by preparing the slurry in a mortar and pestle by adding 40 mg of the sample, 200 L of Nafion (5), and 1 mL of isopropyl alcohol.The obtained paste was coated on FTO with 1 cm 2 area and heated at 250 C for 1 h to get a homogenous film.Mott-Schottky (MS) plots were recorded at a scan rate of 10 mVs in Na 2 SO 3 neutral solution

out using a Thermo K-Alpha spectrometer using microfocused and monochromated Al K radiation with 1486.6 eV energy. 2.3.Photoelectrochemical Measurements.The on-off transient measurements were carried out in a three-electrode system using an Autolab PGSTAT 30 potentiostat under the illumination of a solar simulator (Newport) with an ultraviolet (UV) ( 420 nm) cutoff filter and 100 mWcm 2 power density.AgAgCl was used as the reference electrode, and platinum was used as the counter electrode.The sample

was collected after each run and refreshed by washing with water, and its performance was reevaluated by the aforementioned procedure.
